moves.1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. Bb5+ Bd7 4. Qe2 Nc: We started off with the Sicilian, Canl-Sokolsky attack.
moves.5. c3 Nf6 6. d4 cxd4 7. cxd4 a6: 8. d5 could have been bad for black, so I decided to force white to choose.
moves.8. Ba4 b5: Trying to alleviate the threat on the diagonal and advance my position.
moves.9. Bb3 Bg4: Idea here is to capture d4, or if white moves her queen to d1, d2, or d3, capture the knight so white would have a hard time castling kingside after gxf3.  White would have the choice of either capturing with the pawn, or losing the d4 pawn.
moves.10. Qd3 Bxf3 11. gxf3: This is what black was hoping for, although white can still use this to her advantage.
moves.11... e5: I'm planning on posting my knight on d4 then attacking queenside with my rook.
moves.12. d5 Nd4 13. Bd1 Rc8 14. Nc3: A good defense that will last a while.
moves.14... Qa5 15. Bd2 Qb4: This weakens white's knight but it puts my queen in danger.
moves.16. b3 Qc5 17. Rc1: White's pieces are moving quite well together, although white is out of position.
moves.17... Qb6 18. O-O: At this time, I felt it a good idea to work on the kingside, although white's pawns are in good positions (other than her doubled pawns on f2 and f3).
moves.18... Be7 19. Be3: This move puts my knight on d4 in jeopardy.  For when white moves f4, my knight is only defended by my queen if I capture f4.  Hopefully I can maneuver a pawn to g5 before it gets too bad.  (This was my thinking at the time.  However, I can now see that black will inevitably be down 1 point after the exchange).
moves.19... O-O 20. Kh1 h6 21. f4: I was too late, but there is still hope.  I don't have to capture f4.
moves.21... Kh7: Here white probably has an idea of moving her rook to g1, then following up with her pawn on f5 threatening an unprotected h6 pawn.  I preemptively move my king with an idea of g6, threatening white's pawn on f5, (when moved).
moves.22. f5 g6 23. Ne2: Now black's knight is in big trouble.  White may be up 1 point after the exchange.  I will stall white and try to gain position by capturing white's rook.
moves.23... Rxc1 24. Nxc1 Kg7: I don't want to be in the line of fire of white's queen after an exchange of pawns.  Perhaps it was too early to make this move, (if i should have made it at all).
moves.25. Ne2: Here it is.  I will simply need to refocus my efforts and gain position.  I see a potential opening on the first rank.
moves.25... Qa5 26. Nxd4 exd4 27. Bxd4 g5: I am now down a point, and need to strengthen my defense.  I am worried about the d5 pawn, but I think I can overcome it.
moves.28. Qc2 Qb4 29. Bb2: A safe move, and I am a little worried about e5.
moves.29... Kg8: I am moving my king again to unpin my bishop and put pressure on e4, with the idea of Nh5.
moves.30. f3 Nh5: My idea here is to move my bishop to f6 to challenge white's firm grasp on the long diagonal.  If white moves her pawn to f4, I will simply capture it.
moves.31... Nxf4 32. Rxf4: I did not see this move coming.  Perhaps white saw something black did not see.
moves.32... gxf4 33. Qg2+ Bg5: Anything else would have resulted in a checkmate.  However, this position, (as delicate as it is), gives black the momentum he needs.
moves.34. Be2: A smart move, as I was looking for a captured bishop or exchange of queens.
moves.34... Qe1+ 35. Bf1 Rc8: My idea here it to move my rook to c2.  If white captures my rook with her queen, I will checkmate her with Qxf1#.  This move also grabs hold of the c-file - a very important file in this game.
moves.36. Kg1: Of course, now that idea won't work.
moves.36... Kh7: I think it's time to unpin my bishop.  It could be useful here.  (Although an immediate move by my bishop will still result in a checkmate).
moves.37. h3 Qe3+: The idea here is to move my pawn forward into a mating attack.
moves.38. Kh1 f3 39. Qg3 Qxe4: White's position is now lost, as anything white does will result in either a loss of her queen, a checkmate, or both.  A good game.
